Comment: Here is my first ever competitive game over the board with a long(ish) time control.  It is the first round of the Glasgow Polytechnic Club Championship which I joined a week before this game was played.  My opponent was also a new member of the club and had a bit less experience than me but was still a reasonable opponent.  I will hopefully get round to posting some more of my OTB games here soon, in particular those from my club championship.  Hope you enjoy.

I have recently taken to playing the Sicilian and thought that one of Glasgow's top chess clubs would be a great place to practice.  I have also bought John Emms' book on the Sicilian recently so watch out for that in a couple of months time, my dragon should be red hot.
I am pleased to see my opponent head for the open Sicilian.  I love playing the anti-Sicilians (particularly Morra Gambit) as white, but hate to meet them as black.
My usual
The Italian variation.  Not one I see often, I think it is a little too committing for white.  Better is 3.d4
getting to play for my pet dragon a move early
White defends his hanging pawn
signaling my intention to play the dragon.  My opponent could still transpose back to the main line with 5.d4 cxd4 6.Nxd4 Bg7 7.f3 O-O

?! I got the first inkling that this might just be my night, a feeling which grew stronger as the evening went on.  This move is downright passive, something you cannot afford in any Sicilian, much less the dragon.  Much better is 5.d4
continuing with my dragon set-up, clears the way to castle.
white bundles his king to safety.  With his play already passive after just 5 moves, white is best castling kingside rather than going for an attack race with a QSC.
My king is now where he belongs; time to develop my queenside and hopefully exploit the weak d4
an aggressive move.  I did not know yet that my opponent's game plan was to exchange off as many pieces as possible, I quickly wised up and prevented it.
continuing with my development; I am currently behind in that respect but my position is better

My opponent goes for the exchange.  I was surprised by this move as his bishop was quite a good piece.  This gives me the two bishops 'advantage', which I personally think is overrated, but as you will see, my opponent soon divests himself of his knights too.
The bishop recapture is obvious, keeping my pawns in shape and keeping a watch over the long diagonal
? Losing a pawn.  This should have been played on move 5 when it would have led to an equal exchange.  Black is better.

Snapping up the pawn.  This is the best recapture as I want to keep pieces on the board while my opponent appears keen to swap, the fact that I am a pawn up does not mean that I want to be boring and swap down to an endgame where I can grind out a win.
This looks quite active but it is really just an attempt to swap off the dragon
I have no desire to let the dragon bishop go so I put him back in his lair
